newsitem.title: UK: Silver OTC options trade perks up before expiry.
newsitem.headline: Silver OTC options trade perks up before expiry.

text.p: Business in silver OTC options has perked up since spot prices sagged but no fireworks were expected for Thursday's expiry, dealers said.
Volatilities have failed to rise and some grantors have been wary of upside exposure, they added.
"There's been a bit of interest in silver over the last few days," said one dealer.
When spot prices broke below the key $5.00 level last week, the market saw buying in short-term $4.90 puts, dealers said.
"The vols have stayed low. You could buy the puts for about 17 percent," one said.
Dealers, however, were divided on recent activity, with some seeing business in $4.75 October puts and others seeing a shift to calls.
One European dealer said he had seen buying in longer term calls, from three-month to one-year dates.
"What we are seeing now is a bit more call buying -- people are playing the rebound," he said.
Another dealer said that players have been wary of granting on the upside.
"Nobody wanted to sell any $5.00 calls at the end of this month, it seems to indicate that people are expecting it to jump back up," he said.
"My impression is a general consensus is that everybody is waiting for it to come back up again and it will be sooner rather than later," he added.

Implied volatilities have been stable with October at-the-money options bid at 14.5 to 15.0 percent, December at 16.0 to 16.5 percent, March at 17.0 to 17.5 percent and September 1997 at 18.5 percent.
Open interest was seen centred on $4.90 and $5.00 and the spot price was expected to remain trapped between the two prices until after the expiry, dealers said.
Gold options activity has been slow, with volatilities still near historic low levels, dealers said.
"Gold is dead. No interest whatever," one said.
No concentration of open interest was seen, but instead spread from $380 to $385, leading to a dull expiry.
"Since it has been very, very quiet people have been playing the gamma over the past two weeks and I think everyone has a small position on every dollar from $380 to $385," a dealer said.
"The vols are so low the sellers are having to sell every dollar rather than $380 or $385," another said.
There was still some interest in end-of-year calls, with one dealer citing recent interest in November $390 call options at 5.4/6.3 percent and December $400 options at 5.2/5.6 percent.
At-the-money implied volatilities for October were bid at 4.75 to 5.00 percent, December at 5.25 percent, March at 6.0 to 6.25 and September 1997 at 7.0 percent.
